ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Outlining, developing, and writing a feature-length screenplay. Providing script coverage on other feature-length screenplays. General insight into showbiz and the life of a working writer.
I learned the skills it took to complete the process of writing out a full length screenplay, and the character and world building that comes with it.
How to write a full length feature film.
Marc is a maestro of screenwriting. He has a way of discussing plot, narrative, characters, and conflict that make you think deeply and intensely about your writing.

I learned how to write a feature length screenplay and all the work that comes with writing a feature such as the necessary time that is needed to plan out the story beforehand as well as the revision process after receiving feedback. I also learned from experts in the industry about writing, screenwriting, the film industry itself, and getting started in the industry.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very self-guided by design, for better or worse. Besides weekly work, your only deadlines for your personal script may be things like 'next draft in three months,' which means setting your own schedule. Guest speakers were very strong.
I believe that more emphasis on understanding story structure would massively benefit this class as students would get a better understanding of how to structure their writing.
Can be a bit work heavy reading and writing feedback for each students script every week. Professor brings in lots of knowledgeable guests that are always open to questions from students.

This course really has no weaknesses. The one thing I would have liked is to just read more well written scripts throughout the year. The strengths of the course are Marc's ability to brung in outside critics and the level of writing each student is asked to exemplify.

The strengths are the professional guests who Professor Lapadula brings in to either read a student script and offer their professional notes or to just talk with the class about the film industry and answer any questions that we may have. It was also helpful receiving feedback for each of our drafts from Professor Lapadula, an industry pro, and our peers.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Nice to be able to write a feature-length screenplay for school credit: work hard and you'll come out of it with a good writing sample, which is super valuable. Connection to guest speakers also helpful.
If they want to be a screenwriter, this class is a necessity.
It is required for the screenplay film major, so yes.
Yes. This is one of the best classes at Yale if you are up for the challenge.

Yes, I highly recommend this class. You get to spend the year writing your own feature length screenplay and perfecting it as much as possible. You receive feedback not just from your peers and the professor but also from professionals in the industry. The amount of feedback on each draft is greatly helpful.
